thread.title: Tomorrow is Today
thread.title_full: Tomorrow is Today

posts.author: Max Resetar
posts.title: Tomorrow is Today
posts.text:
SLAMADAMONTH Tomorrow is Today Before they were officially released, Nike gave us a taste of the future with a hands-on training session of the brand new HyperAdapt 1.0. 
December 02, 2016 By Max Resetar 
The future’s always seemed so far off. The movies and TV shows make flying cars, holograms, and talking robots seem like an impossibility. But take a moment to look around and you’re probably reading this on your phone, a super-computer that fits in your pocket. You probably just posted something on the Internet that someone halfway across the world can see and relate to. 
And now we have sneakers that feature a motor, capable of lacing themselves and reading your foot. Nike’s delivered on a fairytale that was done with some Hollywood magic more than 30 years ago . This year’s Mag release was for an incredible cause, but if you didn’t have $200K , you couldn’t scoop that thing. And even if you did have the bread, the Mags aren’t meant for everyday use. 
So while the legendary Tinker Hatfield continued to build the mystique of the Mag in recent years, Tiffany Beers got started crafting her legacy, eventually creating the HyperAdapt 1.0. It took 10 years, but Beers and her team are responsible for the performance sneaker of the future. 
She began by shrinking an industrial-strength motor to a size that would fit into the outsole of a modern Nike silhouette. Then she put a sensor into the heel that reacts to your foot. Once you hit that sensor, the sneaker’s Adaptive Lacing tech takes over and it automatically tightens. She made sure to incorporate Swoosh’s signatures—there’s flawier and Lunarlon foam in the midsole. 
The HyperAdapt has been hyped for a while, for athletes, sneakerheads and the tech crowd. It’s a beautiful sneaker, both aesthetically and from a technological standpoint. And it’s built for the gym, the track and the basketball court. 
In front of Beers herself, Nike laced 10 journalists with the HyperAdapt, putting them through basketball, running and training exercises at 7 in the morning, just three hours before they were available for purchase. 
The hype is real. 
As soon as I put my foot in the sneaker, it tightened accordingly, hugging my foot. It was way lighter than expected, even though it’s got a motor in it. It was comfortable and with its mid-cut, versatile for all three workouts. With the encouragement of Beers and the trainers, I continued to adjust the sneaker’s tightness for each workout. Feet swell the more you use them. The adjustments weren’t just for comfort, they also helped blood circulation and they helped me get more use out of my feet before they were fatigued. 
On the court, we tested lockdown, traction and mobility. Because the HyperAdapt can be tightened until there’s no room left between your foot and the sneaker, the lockdown can be perfect. My feet didn’t move once I was in the sneaker. It was a Zoom Solider LeBron X-level-lockdown with a mix of Kyrie 2 lightness. 
After a few minutes of dribbling and shooting, I completely forgot I was hooping in the HyperAdapt. The comfort and lightness had your boy hitting jumpers like prime Michael Redd. 
It wasn’t tough to wear the shoe. It was on some pillow and blanket luxury. It was tough to comprehend how Beers and her team figured all of it out, somehow combining technology they had no clue about (Beers has said she’s now an expert in batteries) before this process, and sneaker technology. They also had to make sure Nike’s reputation didn’t take a hit with an ugly sneaker. 
Beers has been everywhere recently, from the Today show to every sneaker website, talking about the sneaker. Before we got to try them on, after years of testing, wearing “stealth” pairs everyday, she said, “I still smile when I put them on in the morning.” 
— 
The Nike HyperAdapt is available for purchase right now. Learn how to get your pair. Photos courtesy of Nike. Tags:

thread.title: Nike files 64 patent applications
thread.title_full: Nike files 64 patent applications

posts.title: Nike files 64 patent applications
posts.text:
Nike files 64 patent applications, including 24 for new technology Matthew Kish, Portland Business Journal , KGW 3:14 PM. PST December 02, 2016 nike-campus-knight CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN GOOGLE+ PINTEREST 
Nike Inc. on Thursday filed a burst of patent applications, including two dozen for new technology, the latest sign of the industry's ongoing digital shift and the sportswear giant's aggressive effort to stay ahead of competitors. 
Photos: Nike patent applications 
Patents, and for that matter, patent applications, don't guarantee a product will hit store shelves. But the flurry of applications shows Nike is putting significant resources behind its ongoing efforts to come up with the next big thing . That includes digital technology, which remains a key industry battleground as sporting goods companies develop "smart" shoes and apparel, such as Nike's $720 self-lacing sneaker , which released Thursday. 
Nike declined comment. The company is in an SEC-imposed quiet period ahead of quarterly earnings Dec. 20. 
Innovation has been a focal point under Mark Parker , who became CEO in 2006. Nike has been awarded 639 patents this year, a company record, maintaining a streak of filing at least 500 patents each of the past several years. Its patent activity now rivals some technology heavyweights . 
The Business Journal compiled a database of Nike's patents in July 2014. While it hasn't been updated, it provides a deeper look at Nike's R&D efforts. 
Click through the slideshow above for images from a handful of the patent applications filed Thursday. 
The Portland Business Journal is a KGW News partner.

While Art Basel Miami Beach might bring out the collectors of Hirst, Johns, and Koons, it also brings out a fashionable crew looking to amass an enviable shoe collection. And last night at Komodo Miami, A$AP Rocky and A$AP Bari hosted a dinner to celebrate their special-edition Nike Air Force 1s done in collaboration with their label, VLONE. The resulting black-and-orange kicks were the talk of the evening with guests including models Alina Baikova, Andreja Pejic, Hanne Gaby Odiele, and Jacquelyn Jablonski all taking in the fun. Joining them were a tight-knit group including Michèle Lamy and Venus X, who lingered over delectable bites and fashionable ensembles, some of which came straight from the VLONE pop-up in Miami, open through Sunday.

thread.title: I Went to the Future and Worked Out in Nike's New Self-Lacing Sneakers
thread.title_full: I Went to the Future and Worked Out in Nike's New Self-Lacing Sneakers

posts.author: Perri Konecky
posts.title: I Went to the Future and Worked Out in Nike's New Self-Lacing Sneakers
posts.text:
Nike HyperAdapt 1.0 Workout Review I Went to the Future and Worked Out in Nike's New Self-Lacing Sneakers December 2, 2016 by Perri Konecky 233 Shares 
At 7 a.m., I walked into a blind date with my latest fling: EARL, and no, we didn't meet on Bumble. EARL, Electro Adaptive Reactive Lacing, is the groundbreaking technology used on the brand-new Nike HyperAdapt 1.0 , the self-lacing shoes released Dec. 1. I was lucky enough to try out the futuristic shoes for a workout and it was easily one of the coolest things I've experienced. Did I mention they took 11 years to come to fruition? 
Aside from the innovation behind the kicks, the most surprising part was how comfortable the shoes are. I put them on, knowing that there was a battery-operated system on the bottom of the shoe and could not feel a thing, they were comfortably cushioned like any other workout shoe. 
I stood up and that's when the magic happened — my shoes were automatically tightened based on the sneaker sensing my foot width, perfectly snug. There are two blue buttons on the side to loosen or tighten the shoes based on the activity you're doing. 
You don't have to be tech-savvy or a serious athlete for these kicks, but you do need some deep pockets. Retailing at $720 , the Nike HyperAdapt 1.0 shoes are not cheap, but they're efficient and can be worn for all different kinds of exercise. I played basketball, ran on the treadmill, and did training exercises, while adjusting the tightness based on the different levels of intensity, making this the most exciting sneaker experience since 1989, when Marty McFly laced up during Back to the Future II . 
Well, if you're going to drop $720 on a pair of sneakers, you need know how they they felt during a workout! Training 
Typically, jump squats are not my forte. I tend to wobble and be thrown off balance, but this was definitely not the case with the HyperAdapts. I pushed the top button to tighten the fit of the shoes, leaving no space for wobbling! During lateral shuffles, ladder drills, and more sharp moves, I found myself moving faster than usual because of the snug comfort of the sneaker. Every part of my foot was secured evenly, preventing wobbly, uneasy movements. Basketball 
For the basketball portion of the trial, we focused on footwork and some shooting. I adjusted my shoes to be even tighter than during training because I was worried about ankle support. I saw the most noticeable effect of the HyperAdapts after coming down from a layup (that likely did not make it into the basket), and landing smoothly on the ground. Considering I was standing on a battery that keeps the shoes juiced up for a month, I did not expect to land so comfortably. High-top basketball shoes will be a thing of the past once players get their hands on these kicks. Treadmill 
For the running portion of the trial, I loosened up the shoes and started jogging. As someone who fears looking like Phoebe Buffay with swinging legs, I was relieved to take the treadmill last. But rest assured, running was no problem. The loosened-up shoes made it easier on my knees and lighter on the feet. A video posted by PERRI (@perrikon) on Dec 1, 2016 at 3:31pm PST 
Overall, I was blown away by the shoes. They may be a little out of my price range, but they're just as comfortable as any Nike shoe and are at a level of versatility that the sneaker industry has never seen before. If you're interested in trying out or purchasing the new Nike HyperAdapt shoes, they're available in New York at the Nike+ Clubhouse and Nike Soho. 
Let's all go back to the future! Related:

thread.title: Nike HyperAdapt 1.0 review: What it’s like to wear the self-lacing 'Back to the Future' shoe we've always wanted
thread.title_full: Nike HyperAdapt 1.0 review: What it’s like to wear the self-lacing 'Back to the Future' shoe we've always wanted

posts.author: mrodio
posts.title: Nike HyperAdapt 1.0 review: What it’s like to wear the self-lacing 'Back to the Future' shoe we've always wanted
posts.text:
Home / Life / Gear & Tech December 01, 2016 Nike HyperAdapt 1.0 review: What it’s like to wear the self-lacing 'Back to the Future' shoe we've always wanted After nearly 30 years in the popular imagination and a decade of development, Nike’s most radical sneaker design yet has finally arrived—and it’s ready to hit your feet with 1.21 jigawatts of cool. by Michael Rodio Follow 
Marty McFly’s self-lacing shoes have arrived from the future—and they’re here to stay. 
On Thursday, Nike introduced the game-changing new HyperAdapt 1.0, the first self-lacing sneaker and a dream of sneakerheads and sci-fi geeks alike ever since Michael J. Fox slipped on a pair of custom Nike MAGs in Back to the Future Part II . 
As the name implies, the HyperAdapt is built around the concept of an “adaptive fit,” which basically means that the shoe actually “senses” the contours of your foot and tightens the laces just enough to wrap it up snugly. 
Basically, the HyperAdapt works by giving your feet a hug. A video posted by Men's Fitness (@mensfitnessmag) on Dec 1, 2016 at 6:07am PST 

The compact blue box in the Phylon midsole houses a battery-powered motor, which connects to thin wires that run along the sides of the shoe and connect to the laces. (One of the designers, Tiffany Beers, told us she can’t say exactly how it works, because the patent paperwork isn’t finalized just yet.) 
Hold down one discreet button on the shoe’s collar, and the motor whirrs, loosening the laces—actually braided nylon bands—before automatically cinching them tight. Hit another button and the laces tighten a little more—if you’re about to start up an intense workout, say, or you just want an extra-snug fit. The blue box also lights up as a row of LEDs pulse across the back of the heel. A photo posted by Men's Fitness (@mensfitnessmag) on Dec 1, 2016 at 4:49am PST 

We’ll admit we expected the HyperAdapts to be a bit clunky—at 14 ounces, a size 9 is certainly heftier than your average cross-trainer—but they feel surprisingly light. We wore the HyperAdapts through a quick basketball practice, a treadmill run, and agility drills, and in each case, it was surprisingly helpful to quickly loosen the laces (when on the run) or lock things down (when cutting across turf) with a simple button tap. 
The HyperAdapt comes in any color you want, as long as it’s black with a white midsole and blue highlights. 
That deceptively simple technology is the product of a decade of work in Nike’s most secretive labs, where a team led by legendary designers Mark Parker, Tinker Hatfield, and Tiffany Beers created the real-life version of McFly’s MAGs that Parker and Hatfield first designed back in 1988. 
“In the lab, we constantly thought: ‘How is the athlete going to use this? Because the experience has to be amazing ,’” says Beers, who spearheaded the HyperAdapt project through a decade of development and testing (even while juggling other shoe projects like the Air Jordan 29). “We engineered the entire thing to perform, comfortably. To adjust your laces on the fly, for the lace pressure to be balanced across the foot, to have an auto-lacing system—those are non-negotiable.” 
The tongue of the left shoe is emblazoned with the project's code name, E.A.R.L, which stands for “electro adaptive reactive lacing.” 
Throughout the HyperAdapt’s design process, Beers and her team often hit on new shoe technologies that ultimately became ubiquitous features in Nike’s mainstream lineup. When Nike first introduced the suspension system Flywire in 2008, Beers says, it solved the problem of connecting the laces to the power unit. Flyweave, a specialized Nike fabric introduced with the Air Jordan 29 in 2012, provides the flexibility and strength to keep the shoe together around the Flywire. (Other parts were literally bootstrapped: Part of the collar is held together with 200-lb. test fishing line, she says.) 
Sometimes, the breakthroughs came outside the lab. When Beers and her team were first designing the prototypes, the batteries lasted 20–30 minutes, tops, Beers says. But thanks to advances in battery technology over the design process, the production versions can hold a charge for five to six weeks. The HyperAdapts also come with charging “pucks,” which stick magnetically to the bottom of the shoe and charge the battery wirelessly, as the Apple Watch does. 
“Remember, this is a consumer electronic and a shoe,” she says. “So as we look to take this worldwide, we’ve had to be sensitive to different regulations on tech around the globe.” 
Beers with the HyperAdapt. 'MT2' on the sole stands for Mark, Tinker, and Tiffany—the design team's signature. 
All that innovation comes with a hefty price tag: At $720, these sneakers are in the same league as your boss’s Ferragamos. They’ll be sold by appointment only—they come with a manual —and customers have access to an exclusive HyperAdapt hotline in case they have questions. 
If you want to get a pair of HyperAdapts now, you’ll need to make an appointment at one of two Nike stores in Manhattan—and they’re already booked up through the weekend. (Nike says it’ll be available in major cities across the U.S. in mid-December, with plans to go worldwide after that.) 
Price aside, the question remains: Why, really, would anybody wear the HyperAdapt? 
First: This is undeniably a monumental sneakerhead cred-builder, even if you’re not a Back to the Future fanboy. And if you are a Back to the Future fanboy, then it’s still cheaper than a working hoverboard . (Or, y’know , a new DeLorean .) 
Second, the HyperAdapt is also a major feat in sneaker engineering. By packing a lithium-ion battery and a cinching motor into the sole of a shoe, the Nike team has once again changed expectations of what a shoe can do. Plus, consider Parkinson’s patients (like Michael J. Fox), who can now tighten their shoes with the touch of a button. 
And, of course, thanks to their adjustable laces, HyperAdapts are also capable all-around sneakers. And while they’re almost definitely too pricey for everyday wear, we know they can hold up to your toughest gym routine with ease. 
But if you're still not sold, you can hold out for version 2.0. “I’ve already put in thousands of hours trying to think about what’s next, and what’s down the road,” Beers says. “You’ll be impressed.” 
Marty McFly would be totally stoked. Topics:

thread.title: Nike Zoom LeBron Soldier 10 Is the Most Versatile Basketball Shoe Available
thread.title_full: Nike Zoom LeBron Soldier 10 Is the Most Versatile Basketball Shoe Available

posts.author: Jordan Zirm
posts.title: Nike Zoom LeBron Soldier 10 Is the Most Versatile Basketball Shoe Available
posts.text: Nike Zoom LeBron Soldier 10 Is the Most Versatile Basketball Shoe Available   2016 Holiday Gift Guide: Nike Zoom LeBron Solider 10 2016 Holiday Gift Guide: The Original Hockey Sauce Kit LeBron James Talks About How He Picked Some of His Craziest In-Game Shoes Views 24,936 The STACK Rundown // A 317-Pound Throwdown, a Deadlifting Grandma and the Nike LeBron 13 Elite Views 2,437 The STACK Rundown // RG3's New QB Coach and Kevin Durant's Crazy Kicks Views 2,087 STACK Holiday Gift Guide Views 4,868 The STACK Rundown // NBA 2K16, Stephen Curry's Terrible Scouting Report and LeBron James' Son Does "The Silencer" Views 23,103 The STACK Rundown // An Exclusive Look at USA Basketball's Fresh Nike Olympic Gear 2016 Holiday Gift Guide: VK Insoles By VKTRY LeBron James Nike Poster Hyperlapse Views 50,321 2015 STACK Holiday Wish List: Dharma Yoga Wheel Views 1,231 Previous Next When you're LeBron James, one line of shoes is simply not enough. And while his top line of signature sneakers will release its 14th generation in January with the aptly named Nike LeBron 14, his secondary line of kicks have stolen the headlines since the summer. RELATED : VK Insoles: The First Insole Engineered to Make You Jump Higher and Run Faster Worn by LeBron when he brought the Cleveland Cavaliers back from a 3-1 deficit in the 2016 NBA Finals, the Nike Zoom LeBron Soldier 10 has remained the Akron, Ohio, native's footwear of choice throughout the 2016-2017 NBA season—and for good reason. The 10th iteration of LeBron's Soldier line is by far the best, both in design and functionality. It sits higher above the ankle for better support, features Nike's Zoom cushioning, and, craziest of all, features absolutely no lacing. Instead are three velcro straps that allow the wearer full control over the tightness of the shoe's fit. It's fair to be skeptical about hooping in a shoe held together by velcro, but the Zoom Soldier 10 is one of the sturdiest kicks we've had the pleasure of testing. There's enough give so that your foot doesn't feel like it's being suffocated, but enough support to eliminate any slippage. The colorways have been nothing but heat, too. From the grey and gold version pictured here—which LeBron wore on opening night when the Cavs received their championship rings—to the black and red Ohio State-themed Soldiers that were turned into cleats for the Buckeyes' matchup against Michigan, the Zoom Soldier 10 is the most versatile basketball shoe on the market right now.

thread.title: Nike Celebrates the Energy of the Big Apple with #NYMade
thread.title_full: Nike Celebrates the Energy of the Big Apple with #NYMade

posts.title: Nike Celebrates the Energy of the Big Apple with #NYMade
posts.text:
Nike Celebrates the Energy of the Big Apple with #NYMade Share Share Image 
Oregon may be Nike’s birthplace, but New York City is where passion for the brand is uniquely experienced: a place where sport, creativity and relentless energy collide. 
The Big Apple roots of the swoosh run deep. Whether Alberto Salazar’s three consecutive marathon wins from 1980-1982, the brand’s first “City Attack” campaign in the mid-‘90s or Carmelo Anthony’s legendary 62 points at Madison Square Garden in 2014, the story of the brand threads through every decade and every borough of the iconic city. Share Image Odell Beckham Jr.'s tattoo depicting the New York City skyline 
Along with the opening of a new store in Soho this month, Nike is bringing its love of the city to life with key product, athlete and consumer moments in a new "#NYMade" campaign. Across the city, #NYMade has come to life through posters and digital billboards, all featuring some of the city’s most celebrated sons and daughters – whether they were born in New York or made their reputations there – including Bella Hadid, Victor Cruz, Serena Williams, Nas and Odell Beckham Jr. 
“New York is at the heart of Nike, and Nike is at the heart of New York,” says Alero Akuya, Senior Brand Director for Nike in New York. “We’re celebrating this city and the sport and energy that drive it through our best athletes and products. We understand better than anyone that you have to prove yourself here before you can really say you’re 'New York Made.'” New York Made Share Image 
“I love coming out here in this New York crowd...It's super special, I love it here.” - Serena Williams, Winner of 8 championship titles (six singles, two doubles) since 1999 at New York’s own tennis major 
“New York is the greatest city in the world. The greatest city in the world.” - Nas Share Image 
“New York made me who I am. Like they say, if you can make it here, you can make it anywhere. I truly believe that. This city has a culture that is unique — the passion, the creativity, the people. You use that on a daily basis to drive or inspire you. I just want to continue having success and be an athlete who is shown in a good light in New York City. I want to be a New York Giant for a very long time.” - Victor Cruz 
“Man, New York is what it's all about. The energy in this city is what fuels me to be better each and everyday.” - Odell Beckham Jr. Share Image Nike Soho at 529 Broadway 
The opening of the five-floor, multi-sport, digitally connected Soho door at 529 Broadway brings new energy to Nike’s presence in the city. The brand is also delivering the latest in sport style innovation through the Nike x Kith pop-up at 644 Broadway and NikeLab exclusives at the 21 Mercer store, while the Upper East Side and Flatiron stores cater to runners of every level. And of course, Niketown New York continues to bring the best of Nike to residents and visitors alike. 
Nike is also taking the concept of personalized service to a new level with its Nike+ Clubhouse at 45 Grand Street in Soho. The Clubhouse is a new concept space for consumers to Nike to learn about, try and buy some of the latest Nike innovations, as well as explore everything Nike+ has to offer through 1:1 appointments with Nike’s team of experts. The Nike+ Clubhouse has been a hub for recent high-profile product launches including the Apple Watch Nike+ and the Nike Mag , and is currently the venue for consumers to find out more about the Nike Hyperadapt 1.0 . Nike HyperAdapt 1.0 display at 45 Grand Share Image 
Meanwhile, a new Nike basketball court (Stanton Street Courts) designed by the artist KAWS has generated plenty of buzz as a special giveback to the city. 
To find out more about Nike’s activities in the city that never sleeps, go to nike.com/nyc or follow @nikenyc on Twitter. More From Nike News

posts.title: Nike Vision Launches Its Essential Lifestyle Collection of Sunglasses
posts.text:
More than two years ago, Nike challenged itself to reinvent eyewear for athletes . Today, Nike Vision has officially launched its new Essential Lifestyle collection of sunglasses. Featuring the most cutting edge technology constructed with sports performance and daily demands in mind, as well as designs inspired by a mix of streetwear , skate parks and fashion runways from around the world, the offering rounds out an active day's outfit. The line of sunglasses features durable lightweight nylon frames suitable for daily wear, Max Optics lenses that provide 100% UVA and UVB protection and sharp vision, and six base frames for each of the four styles: the Nike Essential Jaunt (Aviator-inspired curved lens silhouette), the Nike Essential Spree (a timeless square frame with a notched nose bridge), the Nike Essential Venture (a linear, dipped top frame with a strong square shape), and the Nike Essential Chaser (wide, square lenses with softened edges for a retro look). You can find the Nike Vision Essential Lifestyle Collection here .

posts.author: Updated December
posts.title: Video shows thieves steal $3K in Nike sneakers | News 12 Connecticut
posts.text:
Video shows thieves steal $3K in Nike sneakers Updated comments + - The video shows two men entering a three-story apartment complex at Cleveland Avenue. (12/2/16) 
BRIDGEPORT - A pair of burglars in Bridgeport made off with 10 pairs of Nike Air Jordan sneakers worth $3,000, police say, and surveillance cameras caught the crime. 
They also allegedly caused more than $6,000 in damage when they broke in through the front door with a crowbar, police say. 
The video shows two men entering a three-story apartment complex along the 100 block on Cleveland Avenue at 11 a.m. on Nov. 11. Investigators are asking for the public's help catching the intruders. Video Watch News 12 Connecticut Live Trending Most-Viewed News 12 Connecticut Articles 
The video shows the men enter carrying empty bags and leaving a few minutes later — with the same bags noticeably bulging. Police say all of the stolen sneakers came from one apartment. 
Police say the suspects know the victim and were also aware he had many pairs of expensive sneakers in his home.

posts.title: Nike files 64 patent applications, including 24 for new technology | KGW.com
posts.text:
Nike files 64 patent applications, including 24 for new technology Matthew Kish, Portland Business Journal , KGW 3:14 PM. PST December 02, 2016 nike-campus-knight CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN GOOGLE+ PINTEREST 
Nike Inc. on Thursday filed a burst of patent applications, including two dozen for new technology, the latest sign of the industry's ongoing digital shift and the sportswear giant's aggressive effort to stay ahead of competitors. 
Photos: Nike patent applications 
Patents, and for that matter, patent applications, don't guarantee a product will hit store shelves. But the flurry of applications shows Nike is putting significant resources behind its ongoing efforts to come up with the next big thing . That includes digital technology, which remains a key industry battleground as sporting goods companies develop "smart" shoes and apparel, such as Nike's $720 self-lacing sneaker , which released Thursday. 
Nike declined comment. The company is in an SEC-imposed quiet period ahead of quarterly earnings Dec. 20. 
Innovation has been a focal point under Mark Parker , who became CEO in 2006. Nike has been awarded 639 patents this year, a company record, maintaining a streak of filing at least 500 patents each of the past several years. Its patent activity now rivals some technology heavyweights . 
The Business Journal compiled a database of Nike's patents in July 2014. While it hasn't been updated, it provides a deeper look at Nike's R&D efforts. 
Click through the slideshow above for images from a handful of the patent applications filed Thursday. 
The Portland Business Journal is a KGW News partner.

thread.title: Unselfish USA roars past Turkey in NIKE International Friendlies
thread.title_full: Unselfish USA roars past Turkey in NIKE International Friendlies

posts.author:
Jason Dill 
jdill@bradenton.com
posts.title: Unselfish USA roars past Turkey in NIKE International Friendlies
posts.text:
Order Reprint of this Story Lakewood Ranch 
If there’s one word to sum up the United States U-17 National Team in this week’s NIKE International Friendlies, it’s unselfish. 
On Friday, Team USA used its cohesive attack to dismantle yet another foe. This time the U.S. ripped past Turkey, 5-1, at the Lakewood Ranch Premier Sports Campus. 
“In practice, we’re pretty selfish and wanting to work on our own,” U.S. forward Andrew Carleton said. “... But when we come out here, it’s for the team, it’s for the country. We’re playing for a bigger purpose than just individually. And we’re trying to win that trophy on Sunday.” 
The victory coupled with Brazil’s 3-3 draw with Portugal earlier on Friday means the U.S. can win the annual tournament with a draw against Brazil on Sunday. But getting there Friday wasn’t as easy as Wednesday’s 7-1 rout of the Portuguese. 
For the first 15 minutes, Team USA was on the back foot, falling behind 1-0 through a Recep Gül scorcher past goalkeeper Justin Garces. 
“I had the angle pretty well and he was just crafty,” Garces said. “He took a side touch to his left and kind of hit it really quick. And the ball kind of spun outwards. ... It was really tight, and the fact that he hit it high, throws you off a little bit.” 
Despite the conceded goal, Garces — one of three Florida natives on the team — came up big just before the Americans found their game. 
He made two stops within seconds during a Turkish onslaught in the 16th minute. 
“I feel like my stops stopped them a little bit,” Garces said. “And it let my team get back up and get the goal we needed to get back into the game.” 
Then Team USA switched gears and blasted Turkey through the front three of Ayomide Akinola, Joshua Sargent and Carleton. It was the second consecutive match in which the trio excelled. 
Carleton supplied the first two goals, bringing his tournament tally to four. The first one came in the 24th minute off an Akinola cross that Sargent deflected into Carleton’s path. 
And just before halftime, Carleton completed his brace to whip the American Outlaws, a Team USA supporter’s group, into a frenzy behind Garces’ goal. 
Not only did Turkey lose the lead in the final 25 minutes of the first half, but Gül was also lost when he pulled up with a goal scoring chance holding his hamstring. He was stretchered off, and Turkey was without its goal scorer. 
Undeterred, Team USA kept the unselfish theme in the second half when Akinola tapped in the third goal from Sargent, who passed to the wide-open Akinola instead of firing off a shot. 
“That’s a really difficult Turkey team to play against,” USA U-17 head coach John Hackworth said. “And to go down a goal early in the game and not having it go our way, so our resolve, problem-solving and finding a way back into the game was excellent. And then we kept pushing and pushing. And I think we showed our quality in the end.” 
That 60th minute goal was followed seven minutes later with yet another Akinola sitter. 
Midfielder George Acosta beat his marker, then distributed to Akinola in a 2-on-1 break rather than attempt a contested shot. 
And the final tally came four minutes from time with substitute Timothy Weah battering in an empty net rebound following a flurry of American chances. Noteworthy 
▪ For the second time this week, a moment of silence was observed for Chapecoense, the Brazil soccer club that lost 71 of 77 people on board a plane that crashed in Colombia on Monday. 
▪ The last name Weah might ring bells for soccer fans. He’s the son of the legendary George Weah, who is one of the best players to never play in a World Cup after playing internationally with Liberia. Timothy is pretty good, too, playing his club football with PSG, one of the bigger clubs in Europe. 
▪ Friday’s results leaves the U.S. on top with six points and Brazil in second with four points. Portugal and Turkey were eliminated. Team USA and Brazil meet in Sunday’s featured match at 5 p.m.

thread.title: They're real. We slipped on Nike's HyperAdapt 1.0 self-lacing sneakers
thread.title_full: They're real. We slipped on Nike's HyperAdapt 1.0 self-lacing sneakers

posts.author: Digital Trends
posts.title: They're real. We slipped on Nike's HyperAdapt 1.0 self-lacing sneakers
posts.text:
nike hyperadapt self lacing sneakers video interview More Julian Chokkattu/Digital Trends
There is art imitating life and then there’s art driving real-life innovation. Today we look at the latter, where one of the most iconic movie moments from decades ago has inspired one of the biggest sneaker innovations for the decades ahead. The dream of the self-lacing sneaker came from the 1988 film Back To The Future II, which paved the way for the real-world Nike Mag prototype. Now, this self-lacing shoe is ready for its world debut with the December 1 release of the Nike HyperAdapt 1.0, designed by Tinker Hatfield, the mastermind behind 15 iterations of the iconic Air Jordan sneaker. Tiffany Beers, senior innovator at Nike, joined the team working on the HyperAdapt in 2005 and has worked diligently for more than a decade to fit the tech into Hatfield’s vision.
Digital Trends traveled to one of the only physical stores in the world you can currently get your hands on the HyperAdapt 1.0, the Nike+ Clubhouse in New York City’s trendy SoHo area, to speak with Beers and try on all of Nike’s hard work. According to Beers, the HyperAdapt went through roughly five different prototypes before the team decided on the current look.
Using test data to for the right fit To make sure the lacing tension was just right, Nike held what Tiffany calls “perception tests” at the Nike Sports Research Lab with 300 people with shoe sizes 7, 10, and 13. “We had them tell us what was comfortable setting and what was a ‘too tight’ setting,” Beers said. “We calculated some things about that data and figured out what the ‘just right’ setting is.”
Wearing the HyperAdapt 1.0 is best described as form-fitting comfort. The second your foot fits snuggly into the shoe, the built-in sensor detects the foot pressure, causing the HyperAdapt 1.0 to start tightening the laces. The magnetic charger that attaches to the sneaker’s sole is powered through a USB connector. Beers says that design feature allows the charger to be connected to a two-amp portable battery charger , ensuring that both your sneakers and your phone can stay charged on the go.
nike hyperadapt self lacing sneakers video interview tiffany beers More nike hyperadapt self lacing sneakers video interview tiffany beers More nike hyperadapt self lacing sneakers video interview tiffany beers More Read More nike hyperadapt self lacing sneakers video interview tiffany beers More The sneaker knows when to stop tightening once it detects a certain friction threshold. It works well for the most part, but occasionally the left sneaker’s tightening button was unresponsive no matter how hard we squeezed – only later it would resume tightening again. There is a noticeable bump you feel at the bottom of your foot where the battery is, but it does not impede your movements.
What’s next for HyperAdapt 2.0? The next generation of the HyperAdapt may be more Honey, I Shrunk The Kids than Back To The Future II . “The smaller things get, the better it is for wearables, period,” Beers added. “The smallest size we have is a men’s 5.5. That’s just because technology does not let us get smaller at this point.”
More : #SneakerHeads: How a new generation of sneaker fans are taking over the Internet
Beers even hinted that software updates being sent to your sneakers may be possible in the future. Now that Nike has proven it can fit a motor and battery in a sneaker, with further miniaturization, incorporating hardware that connects to the internet seems very possible.
The arrival of the HyperAdapt 1.0 signals that the technology we thought was once only science fiction is now a reality you can buy in the store. But, just as the 1.0 version number in the name suggests, these shoes are just the beginning.
Nike’s power-lacing shoes hit stores today, but good luck finding a pair Nike’s ‘self-lacing’ HyperAdapt shoes will cost you $720 How to get your own pair of Nike’s ‘Back to the Future’ shoes

thread.title: Bears eager to partake in NFL's 'My Cause, My Cleats' campaign - Chicago Tribune
thread.title_full: Bears eager to partake in NFL's 'My Cause, My Cleats' campaign - Chicago Tribune

posts.author: Dan Wiederer
posts.title: Bears eager to partake in NFL's 'My Cause, My Cleats' campaign - Chicago Tribune
posts.text:
On Sunday afternoon, Sam Acho ’s customized Nike cleats will stand out when the Chicago Bears host the San Francisco 49ers at Soldier Field. The shoes will be green and white, in the hues of the Nigerian flag. And they’ll feature a symbol to represent the hospital Acho is helping to build in the rural African village of Isuikwuato.
As part of the NFL's "My Cause, My Cleats" campaign , players across the league are wearing special cleats in Week 13 to highlight a charity or cause they’re devoted to. Among the Bears participating are Acho and running back Jordan Howard .
Acho continues devoting his attention to spreading awareness about Living Hope Christian Ministries , a medical mission devoted, among other things, to improving medical care in parts of Africa. The organization was founded in 1989 by Sam’s father, Sonny Acho, and continues to help provide for local medical clinics, schools and orphanages in Nigeria.
Howard’s cleats will honor the Pulmonary Fibrosis Foundation . Howard’s father, Reginald, died of that disease when Jordan was a child.
Acho made his first medical mission trip to Nigeria with his parents when he was 15 years old. He was, he says, just a wide-eyed and helpful volunteer on that initial trip, helping to escort patients from their medical check-in to the doctors they were hoping to see.
Acho said he was “shocked and amazed” by how much valuable work was being done through the outreach. It instantly heightened his passion for the cause.
“As I got older, instead of that being my parents’ things, it became my thing – something I loved and cared about,” Acho said. “I started to see the doors I could open. Playing in the NFL, I was telling teammates about what I would do in Nigeria and how we could help and seeing who would come.”
While playing for the Arizona Cardinals , Acho persuaded teammates Calais Campbell , Dan Williams and Ricky Lumpkin to accompany him to Nigeria. Last summer, Bears cornerback De’Vante Bausby joined Acho on the trip.
Currently, Acho said, the Living Hope clinic is undertaking a three-phase project to raise $2 million to build the hospital in Isuikwuato. They’ve raised, Acho says, $250,000 of the $300,000 needed to complete the first phase. Acho is hoping his footwear this weekend will encourage others to donate.
Howard, meanwhile, will use his platform to raise awareness for pulmonary fibrosis.
Reginald Howard was 52 years old when he passed away. In his dad’s honor, Jordan’s Adidas cleats on Sunday will be blue and yellow.
“He definitely inspires me. I think about him every day,” the Bears rookie said. “I know he’s always there with me. Even though he’s not here in body, I know he’s here spiritually. He always motivates me.”
Around the league, the “My Cause, My Cleats” campaign will be omnipresent this weekend.
Bears guard Kyle Long has remained active in assisting his older brother, Chris, with his Waterboys initiative, a push to bring clean water to Tanzania and other East African communities in need. Chris will wear cleats highlighting his foundation and the Waterboys cause.
Acho hopes all the cleats worn across the NFL will spur a positive reaction.
“The hope obviously is that this doesn’t become oversaturated,” he said. “At first, I’ll admit I was hesitant to do this. I was thinking, ‘Man, everybody else is going to be doing this. Two-hundred-fifty players all with their own cause. No one’s going to get the message.’ At the same time, this is something near and dear to my heart and if people can hear about this and support it we’ll be able to provide so help.”

posts.title: Vibrant Patterning On The Pendleton x Nike What The Pack
posts.text:
To follow-up on its previous collaboration from last month, Pendleton and Nike join forces once again for the holidays — this time utilizing the Swoosh’s infamous “What The” theme. 
A style that is defined by a mixture of patterns and colorways from previous releases that have been formed into one design — this particular iteration incorporates a variety of tribal patterns in different tones throughout.
Featuring the Air Force 1 High with a gum sole unit, Air Force 1 Low and Air Max 1 — each retails for $170, $160 and $170 respectively. 
Create your own unique pair directly at NIKEiD now, while supplies last.
h/t: Nike 
Author’s Take You can’t go wrong with either silhouette and the design is pretty appealing, and perfect for the season. I prefer it a lot more with gum bottoms too.

posts.author: David Fischer
posts.title: Here Is Your Chance To Get Your Hands On The VLONE x Nike Air Force 1
posts.text:
The collaboration between VLONE and Nike on an Air Force 1 had originally been confirmed in mid November. Following the announcement, the sneaker got a limited surprise release at ComplexCon. But no further roll-out has been officially announced to date. The for now very limited sneaker is coming to the brand’s Art Basel Miami Beach pop-up store that we showed you this week. But unfortunately, standing in line will not do it this time. You can only get your hands on the sneaker via a raffle. Buying a long sleeve t-shirt from the pop-up will give you one raffle ticket and a hoodie will give you two raffle tickets.
Who Knows You Might Win A Pair Of VF1 (Worldwide) – vlone.co

La Salle senior DJ Principe placed 21st in the Nike Cross Nationals at the Glendoveer Golf Course, Portland, Ore., on Saturday.

thread.title: Tuohy 13th out of 200 runners at Nike X-C Nationals
thread.title_full: Tuohy 13th out of 200 runners at Nike X-C Nationals

posts.title: Tuohy 13th out of 200 runners at Nike X-C Nationals
posts.text:
Tuohy 13th out of 200 runners at Nike X-C Nationals Nancy Haggerty , nhaggerty@lohud.com 4:42 p.m. EST December 3, 2016 Buy Photo North Rockland's Kaitlyn Tuohy runs in the state cross-country championships at Chenango Valley State Park in Chenango Forks on Nov. 12th, 2016. (Photo: Chris Kitchen/For The Journal News) Buy Photo 27 CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Her team didn’t get to go, which was a big disappointment. But North Rockland freshman Katelyn Tuohy made the best of things and then some Saturday, earning all-American honors in cross-country by running to a 13th-place finish out of 200 runners in the Nike Cross Nationals in Portland, Oregon. 
Tuohy, whose team finished 10th in the U.S. at last year’s Nike cross-country championship and was ranked fourth in the U.S. overall before a sub-par performance at last Saturday’s Nike New York qualifier, slipped from 16th place to 20th after two miles Saturday. 
But the two-year cross-country veteran, who was second in this year’s Class A State Championship, second in the state Federation Championship and fifth at last week’s qualifier, finished characteristically strong despite an extremely muddy course. 
“I’m kind of small. It was hard getting through. I was trying to get some traction,” Tuohy said post-race by phone, noting she tried to step in the driest areas. 
That approach worked, as did her revamped race plan. 
Despite conditions, Tuohy clocked 17:58.5. Last year, over the same, although less-muddy course, she ran 18:11.60 for 49th place. 
Running without her team, North Rockland coach Brian Diglio said, allowed Tuohy to be less cautious, since she didn’t have to worry about going out too fast, fading and costing North Rockland placements in team standings. 
“She definitely wanted to test herself,” Diglio said. 
“While she’s been focused on team all year long and that’s been her major motivating factor, this time she could focus on herself,” Diglio explained. “We changed our tactics a little bit. She wanted to try to go out a little harder and try to hang with these top girls. Running as an individual, rather than as part of a team, changed her strategy and I think it worked out perfectly.” 
Indeed, Diglio had hoped for a top-20 finisher for his young runner, which would gain her all-American status, since that goes to the top 21. 
Instead, she bettered that by seven slots, a “fantastic accomplishment,” according to the coach, who, like the rest of his team, stayed home after North Rockland finished fourth as a team in the New York qualifier and was bypassed for an at-large bid. 
The 14-year-old indicated a calm approach aided her. 
“It’s the most competitive meet in the U.S. all year. (But) I didn’t get too nervous. Whatever happened happened. It wasn’t a big deal. I was really relaxed. I guess it really helped,” she said. 
Colorado’s Brie Oakley won in 17:10.1. 
Elite runners were so close Tuohy missed a top-10 finish by just 1.4 seconds. 
“The compression between all these girls is really good,” she said. “Going into the race I knew I really had to have a good race or I could end up 20th or 40th.” 
In Oregon with her parents but not team, Tuohy bonded with other New York runners. 
“I missed them a lot,” Tuohy said of her teammates, “but I made a lot of friends this year.” 
And many had much to celebrate. 
Five runners from New York finished in the top 20. And New York won the nine-region regional championship. 
New York’s Fayettville-Manlius won the girls national team title for the 10th time in 11 years. 
Tuohy, who said she’d like to return next year with her team, characterized her finish as “pretty cool,” adding she was proud she executed her race plan well. 
Diglio, though, laughed, saying, “She was actually mad she didn’t finish top-10. She said she would have if I were there.” 
“That’s the mentality of a great runner," he added.

posts.title: Cross country: NB Canyon’s Worley finishes second at Nike Nationals
posts.text:
Cross country: NB Canyon’s Worley finishes second at Nike Nationals By David Hinojosa   6:12 PM Print New Braunfels Canyon’s Sam Worley approaches the finish line of the 6A boys 5K during the UIL cross country state meet at Settlers Park in Round Rock on Saturday, Nov. 12, 2016. (staff photo) 
New Braunfels Canyon senior Sam Worley finished second at the Nike Cross Nationals cross country meet held Saturday in Portland, Oregon. 
Worley, who is signed with Texas, covered the 5,000-meter course at Glendoveer Golf Course in 15 minutes, 35.1 seconds. Worley finished behind Casey Clinger of American Fork (Utah), who won the title for the second-straight season. Clinger finished in 15:28.4. 
Worley improved on his 76th place finish from a year ago. Worley, who won the UIL Class 6A state championship last month, will run in the Fort Locker Nationals in San Diego next Saturday.

thread.title: Nike Presents The Art Of SNKRS – AF1
thread.title_full: Nike Presents The Art Of SNKRS – AF1

posts.author: Andres Carrillo
posts.title: Nike Presents The Art Of SNKRS – AF1
posts.text:
Organically elevating the Air Force 1 s innovative look and deep-rooted heritage, Amsterdam-based photographer and director Joost van Brug first created his signature, symmetrical sneaker images thanks to an interest in his brother’s passion for sneakers and their iconic colorways.
“I wanted to shoot something new with sneakers, and my brother is obsessed with Nikes. To me, his collection is just the same shoe in different colors and a big color palette. I just pick shoes based on the color I like, but he told me the stories behind the colorways in his collection.”
An interest in his brother’s favorites sneakers, and in sneaker culture at large, pushed Joost to explore new methods of capturing their essence. In an effort to create a nonrepresentational image of something as recognizable as an iconic sneaker, Joost ultimately developed a motion blur technique, which captures the colors of iconic kicks as they rotate around an axis point.
“For me, seeing my brother’s collection was just seeing a color change in the same shoe. I thought, ‘What if I just get rid of all the information of a shoe, so you don’t even recognize it as one? If you just have the colors, do you still know what shoe it is?’ That’s how I came up with the abstract motion blur.”
His new abstract technique highlights the iconic colors of Nike’s most eye-catching sneakers, while also giving each shoe a more nuanced, visceral identity.

The post Nike Presents The Art Of SNKRS – AF1 appeared first on KicksOnFire.com .

posts.author: CSN Bay Area staff
posts.title: Draymond Green to wear custom 'Sideline Racism' Nike shoes
posts.text:
Draymond Green to wear custom 'Sideline Racism' Nike shoes Draymond Green to wear custom 'Sideline Racism' Nike shoes By CSN Bay Area staff December 03, 2016 5:39 PM 
For all Week 13 NFL games, players have the clearance to wear custom-designed cleats to highlight a cause that they are passionate about. And Draymond Green is joining the movement with his Nike shoes this weekend. 
Green will wear specially designed yellow and blue Nikes that read, "Sideline Racism." On Twitter, Green wrote "I stand with my @NFL brother this weekend in wearing @RISEtoWIN's Sideline Racism shoes in uniting against racism. We stand united @NFL." 
The shoes are through RISEtoWIN, whose Twitter profile states the organization as "dedicated to harnessing the unifying power of sports to improve race relations." 
RISE (the Ross Initiative in Sports for Equality) is a non-profit organization, which was founded by Miami Dolphins owner Stephen Ross in 2015. I stand with my @NFL brothers this weekend in wearing @RISEtoWIN ’s Sideline Racism shoes in uniting against racism. We stand united @NFL pic.twitter.com/jHymLXnhNU

posts.author: Brian Farmer
posts.title: Nike’s Zoom Talaria Mid Flyknit Arrives in “Baroque Brown” Colorway
posts.text:
Visit the original post to see all 2 images from this gallery. 
The return of designer Tinker Hatfield’s ’97 running classic, the Nike Zoom Talaria Mid Flyknit, has been updated for winter and arrives in a new “Baroque Brown” colorway.
The one-piece, woven Flyknit upper integrates areas of high breathability, stretch and support, conforming to the shape of your foot for a comfortable, second-skin fit. It’s layered with no-sew films and a DWR (durable, water-repellent) finish to keep your feet dry, while a mid-cut collar provides a snug, supportive fit and enhances coverage in chilly conditions.
The sneaker’s aggressive outsole pattern offers enhanced traction on cold and wet surfaces, while the exaggerated heel provides extra durability. As a nod to the original, a reflective heel counter is debossed with “Talaria” for heritage style and enhanced visibility in low light.
Featuring contrasting turquoise laces, the Nike Zoom Talaria Mid Flyknit “Baroque Brown” is now available at retailers like Livestock for approximately $200 USD.

posts.author: WSJ
posts.title: With $720 Self-Tying Sneaker, Nike Loosens Ties to Retailers
posts.text:
39:55 AM PST by Red in Blue PA 
Nike Inc. this week begins selling a pricey sneaker with self-tying laces, a high-stakes test of the companys technology investments and efforts to sell more products directly to consumers. 
Since its founding, Nike has predominantly been a wholesaler. But as shopping shifts online, Nike is moving to lessen its reliance on retailers. It wants to double its direct sales to consumers to $16 billion by 2020, particularly as rivals Adidas AG and Under Armour Inc. have become more competitive in recent years. 
That is where the self-lacing $720 HyperAdapt sneakers play a role. The company is offering the shoes exclusively on its relaunched Nike+ app and at a new retail store in New York City, beginning on Thursday. The idea is to hook consumers into buying via its app or visiting Nike stores for limited-edition sneaker releases, which to date has been a near-weekly phenomenon at Foot Locker and other retailers. thread.title_full: Now 12 of 12 College Football Playoff teams have been Nike schools

posts.author: Richard Johnson
posts.title: Now 12 of 12 College Football Playoff teams have been Nike schools
posts.text:
Eat it, adidas.
In the interest of corporate brand synergy and marketing, Nike would like you to know that they again outfit all four Playoff entrants.
Any Field. Every Time. #CFBPlayoff https://t.co/EDDQMoQd2V pic.twitter.com/oaZC15tfCd 
— Nike Football (@usnikefootball) December 4, 2016 Alabama, Washington, Ohio State and Clemson all rep swoosh swag. And the last few seasons, the apparel brand has bedazzled up the swoosh to make it really pop. They’ll do it again this time around : 
The Alabama Crimson Tide, The Ohio State Buckeyes and Clemson Tigers will be in the Nike Vapor Untouchable Speed uniform with the Washington Huskies wearing the Speed Machine Hypercool uniform during the College Football Playoff, each featuring a fractal diamond Swoosh on the front of the jersey and pant.
2015:
2014:
Nike sponsors over half of the FBS, and its dominance is clear at the top. Besides outfitting each Playoff team, the other major apparel brands ( adidas and Under Armour) have barely even gotten close to getting a team in the Playoff. In each of the final top 10s of the Playoff era, there have only been two total non-Nike squads. Notre Dame (Under Armour) finished No. 8 in 2015 and Mississippi State (adidas) finished No. 7 in 2014. There likely will not be any non-Nikes in the 2016 top 10, other than Wisconsin.

thread.title: Nike uniforms for College Football Playoff: Alabama, Clemson, Ohio State, Washington - CBSSports.com
thread.title_full: Nike uniforms for College Football Playoff: Alabama, Clemson, Ohio State, Washington - CBSSports.com

posts.author: Chip Patterson
posts.title: Nike uniforms for College Football Playoff: Alabama, Clemson, Ohio State, Washington - CBSSports.com
posts.text:
21m ago • 1 min read 
The College Football Playoff bracket has been set. There are fans that are thrilled and searching for tickets and other fans, like those in State College, Pennsylvania or Ann Arbor, Michigan, frustrated that the College Football Playoff Selection Committee did not include their team in the top four. 
But no one is happier than the folks at Nike football. For the third straight year, all four CFP teams are Nike schools. Saturday's announcement came with the release of four mock-ups of the alternate uniforms for the playoff, all from the Nike Vapor Untouchable line in 2016. — Nike Football (@usnikefootball) December 4, 2016 
As SB Nation's Land Grant-Holy Land noted, the Ohio State uniforms in the promo are the same ones worn by the Buckeyes for the double-overtime win against Michigan. But if Clemson, as the No. 2 seed and "home" team in the Fiesta Bowl, wears its home orange, then Ohio State will likely be in white jerseys. 
The same is expected to be the case for Washington as the "road" team against Alabama in the Peach Bowl. Unlike the Nike Mach Speed template worn by many Nike teams in 2016, the new Nike Vapor Untouchable look features less seams and panels along with the latest uniform technology.

Nike Basketball will be starting the Christmas season a little early this year as they’ll begin releasing their first Christmas-themed sneaker of the year tomorrow.
Kevin Durant does the honors as his KD 9 will be releasing in this “The Sauce” colorway that you see above. Believe to be inspired by cranberry sauce (that is typically eaten during the holidays), this KD 9 features a full Deep Burgundy upper with Bright Crimson hits on the inner liner and the front portion of the Flyknit. Metallic Red Bronze is then placed on the Swoosh branding on the side panels.
You can pick up the Nike KD 9 The Sauce at select Nike retailers beginning tomorrow, December 5th for $150.
via: Nike 
Author’s Take Solid colorway of the KD 9. Love the burgundy upper, but could have done without the crimson accents.

thread.title: NationBuilder
thread.title_full: NationBuilder

posts.author: KTG
posts.title: NationBuilder
posts.text: Capture Moments // Create Sounds // Be happy // Help others smile // and… I just want Nike gear. 37 mins ago NationBuilder Hello Medium, The name is Kam and I am nervous as hell at the thought of folks reading this. I’m exposing myself to a potential onslaught of negative energy, I’ve come across negative energy aimed at the company (and employees), I’m not sure how my fellow coworkers at NationBuilder will react or what they will think, I tend to care less about filtering myself (so there is a high possibility of profanity) and lastly I’ve never done anything like this. I work for NationBuilder, I call myself our “Defender Against the Dark Arts” * (still want my job title switched to that). * Working here is for lack of a better word, different. I use the word different for various reasons and I hope to explain in this post or whatever they’re called on Medium. I have my * ”be the black guy version of yourself that makes everyone feel comfortable around you feeling” *everyday I come into work. This is something I deal with everyday and I’m great at making those who don’t look like me feel ok around me and to wake up and come in and not instantly get that gut feeling is really brilliant. One of the things here at NationBuilder is the idea of being your “true self” and this is something I hold dear to my heart and I do best to, one figure out who my true self is and show up to work being that man. In my short time here I’ve had the privilege of meeting some of the most intellectually, emotionally and socially brilliant folks ever. I get to sometimes have cool dialogue with our CEO Jim, have one of the most powerful moments in my life with our President Lea, bug Amy and Young Thugger (Happy Birthday Young Hater) , dance around the office while I’m in my world and notice Ashlee and A’ja laughing at me and make fun of and connect with the stupefying Jesse C.* (I really enjoy our conversations and growing our friendship). * I could go on and on * (Shoutout to Dom, Ryan and Joe) * It seems that I am somehow able to add to this little community we have in our office and that blows my mind daily. Here at NationBuilder i’ve connected with folks that I developed true friendships with and opened up to complete strangers * (which goes against my survival instincts as a male black) *. This is astounding to me. I have an eccentric, BAM in your face personality (I’m working on refining it) and it appears that folks at NationBuilder accept it. When I hear and read some of the mean spirited comments about the company employees being racist or allowing evil blah blah blah it does bum me out, because I see the power of this overlooked thing called Empathy that NationBuilder is holding and in it’s own way giving to everyone. I struggled with the thought of allowing anyone to use NationBuilder’s product and spew whatever venom they wanted to spew. I struggled greatly with the idea that I have to just sit on the sidelines and do nothing when I see someone becoming the face of something that will more than likely make my day to day life a tad more challenging. I don’t know what changed, yet now I enjoy the thought that there is a platform that gives everyone access. Be it a racist individual, a TRILL individual (urban dictionary it for those not about the Trill life) or one who is strong with the SWIRV * (I’ll probably do another post about SWIRV and the coming SWIRV movement) *I enjoy it because this is one of the few things I know of that gives everyone access. Having access is key to creating change. Change is something this country needs a greatly. I had to think long and hard about continuing to work here because of my being called an “Uncle Tom” by someone close to me. The individual felt that because NB allowed Donald Trump to use the software and me working at NB means that I am aiding an individual who clearly is racist and legitimizing racist thoughts and behaviors for others. This thinking is maybe what led to my change of thought. If NB started saying who could and could not use it’s product where does the line stop? It seems like such a slippery slope and I already think that we are in a catch 22. No matter which side you look, someone will have an issue with what someone else is doing or saying. I ask that folks work to find some empathy and attempt to accept that we don’t have to get folks to be on our side to coexist in a thriving community. Those who have the courage and determination to make a change I encourage you be the change you want and look at NationBuilder, the folks working here are passionate about what they do and more importantly open to learning about the things they don’t see everyday. I am proud that I’ve been able to share stories with peers that have told me it helped them understand the black experience more, I definitely wish we could have more of these discussions. It’s a rare thing to find people who understand that they are ignorant to something and want to become more knowledgeable and understanding. I say this as a man who sees a system that isn’t setup for me to thrive and NationBuilder’s mission gives me hope. Jyn Erso said it best, “rebellions are built on hope.” I have hope that this company can achieve it’s mission and democratize democracy. That shit would be so dam cool. So before you decide to send a Tweet or anything like that remember there is a human (robots haven’t taken all the jobs yet) who sees this and they more than likely are doing what they think is the right thing to do. I hope that this helps someone who could be working on something that will make a positive impact and needed a push about using NationBuilder or anything else. Know that no one here at NationBuilder asked me to do this or has any idea I would be doing this. This is me getting out of my comfort zone and hoping that I can share another voice from NationBuilder. I leave you with a word from a great Wizard I know named Lord V “SWIRV,”

thread.title: Four-star athlete Greg Johnson decommits from Arizona Wildcats
thread.title_full: Four-star athlete Greg Johnson decommits from Arizona Wildcats

posts.author: Zack Rosenblatt Arizona Daily Star
posts.title: Four-star athlete Greg Johnson decommits from Arizona Wildcats
posts.text:
Tom Hauck 
Arizona commit Greg Johnson at the 2016 Nike Football The Opening in Portland, Oregon. (Photo credit: Nike) Four-star athlete Greg Johnson decommits from Arizona Wildcats Tom Hauck 
Arizona commit Greg Johnson at the 2016 Nike Football The Opening in Portland, Oregon. (Photo credit: Nike) 
It was assumed Arizona would feel the impact of Donte Williams ' likely impeding departure for Nebraska rather quickly, at least in recruiting. 
Sunday, the Wildcats lost the centerpiece of their highly-regarded 2017 recruiting class, and it's likely connected to the Williams news. 
Greg Johnson announced on Twitter he "decided to re-open my recruitment" after being verbally committed to the Wildcats since March. Johnson surprised many when he made that early commitment ot the Wildcats, but Johnson picked the Wildcats primarily because of his relationship with Williams. 
Williams' departure for Nebraska in particular is interesting because of how the Cornhuskers have been recruiting Johnson even as he was committed to Arizona. 
Johnson took an official visit to Nebraska late in the season and told the Star afterward: "It was cool, just being out of California for a couple days. The atmosphere was cool, and they are cool people out there so I enjoyed it overall. It was a cool visit." 
With Arizona out of the picture, Nebraska and USC are expected to be the leaders for Johnson, whose decision has wide-ranging impact for the UA. 
For one, Johnson is the recruit that started a flurry of commitments over the summer and into the season, helping the UA get its class as high as 27 players and for a while rated the top class in the Pac-12. Now, Arizona is down to just two four-star recruits committed to its 2017 class: quarterback Braxton Burmeister and running back Nathan Tilford . 
Johnson is rated the No. 2 athlete in the West, according to Scout.com , and was expected to play cornerback at Arizona. 
His departure likely puts the death knell on Arizona's pursuit of five-star receiver Joseph Lewis , Johnson's teammate at Augustus Hawkins High School in Los Angeles. It's long been believed that Lewis and Johnson wanted to play together in college, and Williams was the primary recruiter on Lewis as well. Nebraska has been considered the favorite for Lewis for much of the recruiting cycle. 
It's unclear how this impacts the rest of Arizona's 2017 class, but it's less likely to impact the players already committed as much as UA's targets for the next class or two, namely four-star cornerback Thomas Graham , recruited by Williams and from Rancho Cucamonga, California. 
Toward the end of Arizona's season, the Star spoke with Johnson about Arizona's incoming recruiting class and his thoughts on Arizona's losing a lot of games this past year. Here's some of what he said. 
"I’m pretty sure we’re all going to be successful there (Arizona) next year, and help Arizona get a lot of Ws." "I’ve been watching the games, I know they’ve been dealing with a lot of injuries and stuff, but I’m pretty sure they’ll get a couple more Ws. I know that when myself and the rest of the 2017 class gets there we’re going to change a lot of that. We’re looking forward to getting a lot of wins and a lot of bowl wins." "They’ve (Arizona's coaches) been saying they know what’s going on right now but they feel with the guys committed right now, they recruited them for a reason, and that’s to come in and change things. That’s what they talk about.

thread.title: Nike To Invest More In Direct-To-Consumer Business; Facebook Is Testing OTT Ad Targeting
thread.title_full: Nike To Invest More In Direct-To-Consumer Business; Facebook Is Testing OTT Ad Targeting

posts.author: AdExchanger
posts.title: Nike To Invest More In Direct-To-Consumer Business; Facebook Is Testing OTT Ad Targeting
posts.text:
Nike To Invest More In Direct-To-Consumer Business; Facebook Is Testing OTT Ad Targeting by AdExchanger // 
Here's today's AdExchanger.com news round-up... Want it by email? Sign-up here . 
Get In The Game 
Nike has historically distributed through retail channels, but by 2020 it hopes to double its $8 billion direct-to-consumer business , relying heavily on digital channels. “As shopping shifts online, Nike is moving to lessen its reliance on retailers,” writes The Wall Street Journal. For instance, the kinds of exclusive sneaker releases it’s done with stores are shifting to its relaunched app. It isn’t a coincidence that last week Nike also announced a lifetime billion-dollar deal with Portuguese futbol star Cristiano Ronaldo. 
Streaming Power 
Facebook has been quietly testing OTT ad targeting, Bloomberg reports. “For the past few weeks ... it’s been targeting ads to people streaming certain shows on their Roku or Apple TV set-top boxes. It customizes commercials based on the Facebook profiles tied to the IP addresses doing the streaming, according to a company spokesman.” So far, A+E Networks and Tubi TV are involved. Questions still remain around who should be responsible for ad sales and how revenue should be split, as well as how to measure ad effectiveness (and those are pretty important questions). More . 
Growing Pains 
WPP talked “horizontality” at an investor event last week. After noting growth would be relatively flat, the holding company expanded on its plans to integrate a diverse array of assets. “The more services an agency group and the more integrated a specific team (e.g., Team Ford) is with their client (and involved in more higher-level strategic work), then we think there is less risk of an agency group losing that particular piece of business,” a WPP spokesperson told investors. WPP’s most recent evolution toward this goal is through [m]Platform , which centralizes tech and data expertise. More at MediaPost . 
Privacy At All Costs 
The EU’s General Data Protection Regulation, launching in May 2018, will prevent businesses from using individual data without explicit consent. Ad tracking and targeting companies will have to receive consent at every point in the tracking chain, a requirement that could “rip the digital ecosystem apart,” as PageFair exec Johnny Ryan hyperbolically puts it. "Companies who create value only by using data and tracking people across the internet will have to find a way to build a relationship with the customer,” he said. “They will have their businesses seriously disrupted. Publishers may finally have the upper hand.” More . 
But Wait, There’s More!

thread.title: Bears eager to partake in NFL's 'My Cause, My Cleats' campaign
thread.title_full: Bears eager to partake in NFL's 'My Cause, My Cleats' campaign - Chicago Tribune

posts.author: Dan Wiederer
posts.title: Bears eager to partake in NFL's 'My Cause, My Cleats' campaign
posts.text:
On Sunday afternoon, Sam Acho ’s customized Nike cleats will stand out when the Chicago Bears host the San Francisco 49ers at Soldier Field. The shoes will be green and white, in the hues of the Nigerian flag. And they’ll feature a symbol to represent the hospital Acho is helping to build in the rural African village of Isuikwuato.
As part of the NFL's "My Cause, My Cleats" campaign , players across the league are wearing special cleats in Week 13 to highlight a charity or cause they’re devoted to. Among the Bears participating are Acho and running back Jordan Howard .
Acho continues devoting his attention to spreading awareness about Living Hope Christian Ministries , a medical mission devoted, among other things, to improving medical care in parts of Africa. The organization was founded in 1989 by Sam’s father, Sonny Acho, and continues to help provide for local medical clinics, schools and orphanages in Nigeria.
Howard’s cleats will honor the Pulmonary Fibrosis Foundation . Howard’s father, Reginald, died of that disease when Jordan was a child.
Acho made his first medical mission trip to Nigeria with his parents when he was 15 years old. He was, he says, just a wide-eyed and helpful volunteer on that initial trip, helping to escort patients from their medical check-in to the doctors they were hoping to see.
Acho said he was “shocked and amazed” by how much valuable work was being done through the outreach. It instantly heightened his passion for the cause.
“As I got older, instead of that being my parents’ things, it became my thing – something I loved and cared about,” Acho said. “I started to see the doors I could open. Playing in the NFL, I was telling teammates about what I would do in Nigeria and how we could help and seeing who would come.”
While playing for the Arizona Cardinals , Acho persuaded teammates Calais Campbell , Dan Williams and Ricky Lumpkin to accompany him to Nigeria. Last summer, Bears cornerback De’Vante Bausby joined Acho on the trip.
Currently, Acho said, the Living Hope clinic is undertaking a three-phase project to raise $2 million to build the hospital in Isuikwuato. They’ve raised, Acho says, $250,000 of the $300,000 needed to complete the first phase. Acho is hoping his footwear this weekend will encourage others to donate.
Howard, meanwhile, will use his platform to raise awareness for pulmonary fibrosis.
Reginald Howard was 52 years old when he passed away. In his dad’s honor, Jordan’s Adidas cleats on Sunday will be blue and yellow.
“He definitely inspires me. I think about him every day,” the Bears rookie said. “I know he’s always there with me. Even though he’s not here in body, I know he’s here spiritually. He always motivates me.”
Around the league, the “My Cause, My Cleats” campaign will be omnipresent this weekend.
Bears guard Kyle Long has remained active in assisting his older brother, Chris, with his Waterboys initiative, a push to bring clean water to Tanzania and other East African communities in need. Chris will wear cleats highlighting his foundation and the Waterboys cause.
Acho hopes all the cleats worn across the NFL will spur a positive reaction.
“The hope obviously is that this doesn’t become oversaturated,” he said. “At first, I’ll admit I was hesitant to do this. I was thinking, ‘Man, everybody else is going to be doing this. Two-hundred-fifty players all with their own cause. No one’s going to get the message.’ At the same time, this is something near and dear to my heart and if people can hear about this and support it we’ll be able to provide so help.”

posts.text: Nike Mercurial Superfly Discovery - The Making of Cristiano Ronaldo's New Boots in Italy   Nike's pro player boots are handcrafted in Italy. Today, Nike gave us a unique behind the scenes look at the production of the brand-new Nike Mercurial Superfly Cristiano Ronaldo Discovery soccer cleats . The Nike Mercurial Superfly Cristiano Ronaldo Discovery soccer cleats are Chapter 3 of the Nike Mercurial Superfly CR7 story that will contain 7 boots in total that describe his rise from the volcanic island Madeira to one of the greatest footballers on the planet. The Nike Mercurial Superfly Chapter 3 CR7 boot pays homage to the match between Sporting and Man Utd in 2003 when Cristiano Ronaldo was discovered by the scouts of the English club. Nike Mercurial Superfly Cristiano Ronaldo Discovery Located in Montebelluna, the north of Italy, the small and exclusive Italian Nike factory specializes solely in the production of brand's top-of-the-line products and professional athletic boots. The images released by Nike include a tech sheet featuring the colors and materials used for each part of the cleats, the actual mold used to fit Cristiano Ronaldo's as well as Neymar's personal boot as well as images detailing the molding and craft process. thread.title: Jewish Teen Gets $25K Bar Mitzvah Money, Buys 800 Nike Pairs To Donate To Less Fortunate Kids
thread.title_full: Jewish Teen Gets $25K Bar Mitzvah Money, Buys 800 Nike Pairs To Donate To Less Fortunate Kids

posts.title: Jewish Teen Gets $25K Bar Mitzvah Money, Buys 800 Nike Pairs To Donate To Less Fortunate Kids
posts.text:
Jewish Teen Gets $25K Bar Mitzvah Money, Buys 800 Nike Pairs To Donate To Less Fortunate Kids By Amanda Moore   04:00 am Drew Frank loves collecting shoes and turned his passion into helping others for his bar mitzvah project.(Photo : Alberto E. Rodriguez/Getty Images ) 
A Jewish teenager, who received $25,000 for his bar mitzvah, bought several pairs of shoes with his birthday money. But the 800 Nike pairs he purchased weren't for his own use. 
Instead, Drew Frank donated these shoes to less fortunate children in low-income families. The 13-year-old tied up with the Braden Aboud Foundation for his special bar mitzvah celebration. 
The Jewish teen asked relatives and friends to give him cash for his birthday, in lieu of gifts. He initially had planned on buying shoes and socks for the kids at the Beall Elementary School in El Paso, Texas. But he also had extra money to donate shoes to orphans staying at the YWCA center for women and children, Kveller reports. 
Drew Frank said that he's been always passionate about sneakers and wanted this to be his bar mitzvah project. Jewish teens are apparently required to do community service in line with this religious tradition. "So I decided to raise money to buy sneakers for kids who are less fortunate than me," the 13-year-old said, per El Paso Inc . 
The Jewish teen celebrated his birthday in May and had over 250 guests who handed out checks. Then, with the help of the foundation that has been spearheading shoe donations to low-income families, they sought Nike for the bulk orders. The shoes have been recently distributed to the school kids as shared in the Braden Aboud Foundation social media account. Another great shoe giveaway ...420 pair of Nike tennis shoes to Beall Elementary ...thank you Drew Frank who gave his Bar Mitzvah gifts to help kids B STRONG! #bstrong #nike #justdrewit #livetogive #tennisshoes A video posted by @bstrongrunwalk on Nov 7, 2016 at 6:35pm PST 
Drew's parents, Dana and Adam Frank, supported his plan and were more than pleased by their son's idea. "We always try to instill the importance of giving back to the community through volunteering and generosity," Dana told the press. 
Doing philanthropic work has always been a family engagement as the Jewish teen's grandparents are well-known philanthropists Stanlee and Gerald Rubin. The Frank kids have also volunteered for Make-A-Wish Foundation on several instances. © 2016 ParentHerald.com All rights reserved. Do not reproduce without permission. Related Articles

The Boca Juniors 2017 third kit introduces a gradient design in blue and white and will be worn during the next 12 months. Boca Juniors 2017 Third Kit This is the new Nike Boca Juniors 2016-2017 third jersey. Based on Nike's current third shirt template, the new Boca Juniors 2017 third shirt fades from navy at the top to sky blue at the bottom. This rather clean base of the Boca Juniors 2017 third kit, quite similar to the club's home uniform, is paired with white, used for the Swoosh as well as BBVA and Huawei sponsor logos, to create a smart look. What do you think? Share your thoughts on the new Boca Juniors third kit below.

posts.text:
Source: Thinkstock The market seesawed last week, digesting some of the big gains since the election in early November. With 2016 almost over, many portfolio managers and investors are looking to make some changes as the time for tax loss selling is upon us. With the futures trading higher this morning, we may open the week with some solid gains and new all-time highs.
24/7 Wall St. reviews dozens of analyst research reports each morning to find new trading and investing ideas for its readers. Some analyst calls cover stocks to buy, while others cover stocks to sell or avoid.
These are this Monday’s top analyst upgrades, downgrades and initiations.
Air Products Inc. (NYSE: APD) was raised to Buy from Neutral at Citigroup. The 52-week trading range for the stock is $106.05 to $146.01. Its consensus price objective is $148.89. The shares closed last Friday at $144.55.
Arista Networks Inc. (NASDAQ: ANET) was downgraded to Equal Weight from Overweight at Morgan Stanley. The shares have traded in a 52-week range of $52.51 to $96.84. The consensus price objective is $91.73. This could be a valuation call.

terms and conditions   Flowserve Inc. (NYSE: FLS) has the firm’s price target raised to $135 from $123 at Stifel,which maintained a Buy rating. The firm cited the company’s broad exposure to the oil and gas markets for the price increase. The 52-week range is $33.86 to $52.50.
